Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Finding the optimum pumping quantity and frequency of freshwater into Neuces Delta Marsh, Texas
Award.AbstractNarration:
The marine organisms living on or in the sediment in the Nueces Delta Marsh, Texas have been adversely affected by increasing salinity. The salinity has been increasing because freshwater flow has been reduced through the construction of dams. In an effort to reduce the salinity a pipeline was constructed to pump freshwater directly into the marsh. To determine the optimum pumping conditions, with regard to these organisms, copepods will be collected at three sites within the immediate area of the pump outflow. Copepods are a good choice because they are the second most abundant group of animals within their size class, are affected by salinity changes, and are often preferred food for juvenile demersal fish, shrimp, and polychaete worms. However, there are very few remaining scientists who study this size class of benthic animals and even fewer copepod taxonomists in the United States. Therefore, this research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Wonchoel Lee, a noted expert on copepod taxonomy, at Hanyang University in South Korea.

This project will provide decision makers with information to better manage the local environment, increase the number of taxonomically trained scientists in the United States, and possibly new genetic and taxonomic data for copepods. Core samples and water measurements are being collected from 3 stations quarterly and from the station nearest the freshwater inflow every two weeks. To this end the following information will be determined during the different pumping patterns: the abundance of copepods, the taxonomic composition of copepods, and the dominate species. All taxonomic data and species descriptions generated will be uploaded to the Gulf of Mexico Research Initiative Information and Data cooperative (GRIIDC). This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The marine organisms living on or in the sediment in the Nueces Delta marsh, Texas have been adversely affected by increasing salinity. The salinity has been increasing because freshwater flow has been reduced through the construction of dams. In an effort to reduce the salinity, a pipeline was constructed to pump freshwater directly into the marsh. To determine the optimum pumping conditions, with regard to these organisms, copepods are being collected at three sites within the immediate area of the pump outflow. Copepods are a good choice because they are the second most abundant group of animals within their size class, are affected by salinity changes, and are often preferred food for juvenile demersal fish, shrimp, and polychaete worms.  However, there are very few remaining scientists who study this size class of benthic animals and even fewer copepod taxonomists in the United States. Therefore, this research has be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Wonchoel Lee, a noted expert on copepod taxonomy, at Hanyang University, South Korea. 

     During the two month duration of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) program the skills needed to identify copepods to species were learned under the instruction of Dr. Wonchoel Lee and his graduate student Kichoon Kim.  These skills are valuable to the study of copepods living on or in the sediment as there are few copepod taxonomists remaining in the United States.  The skills learned included correct mounting of individuals on microscope slides for identification,  building dissection tools, building sorting tools,  learning dissection techniques, learning molecular techniques, learning drawing techniques using a microscope, and identification.  Through the use of these learned skills a total of 158 copepods were identified from Nueces Delta marsh, Texas belonging to 2 orders, 6 families, at least 4 genera, and at least 5 species.  

     This project not only aided in the sharing of scientific techniques but also in fostering cultural experiences and through it cultural understanding.  The cultural experiences gained will aid in future collaborations.  The 12th International Conference on Copepoda and pre-conference workshop were held in South Korea and provided further experience in identifying copepods and helped foster future international research collaborations not only with the member's of Dr. Wonchoel Lee's lab at Hanyang University but among attending scientists and students from all over the world.  These cultural experiences will also be shared with 4th graders as part of a unit on understanding how people organize themselves.
